div.head: Editorial team
div.p: Joyce Reynolds (VIAF, Wikipedia, British Academy) collected and prepared numbers 1-996, with the support of many colleagues in Libya and elsewhere.
Caroline Barron (ORCID) added the Punic to all the multi-lingual texts
Charlotte Roueché (ORCID) continued and standardised the editing, adding further texts and references, bibliography and translations.
Alessandra Giovenco (BSR) curated the enrichment of the BSR photographic collection, and the interoperability of the resources.
Hafed Walda provided the geodata, which formed the basis from which Neil Jakeman created the Heritage Gazetteer of Libya.

div.head: Delivery
div.p: Irene Vagionakis, ORCID established and developped the basic architecture and design of the site

Gabriel Bodard (ORCID) worked with Roueché and Vagionakis on the editing and standardisation of texts, and also oversaw the digitisation and the construction of the publication, and use of EpiDoc standards. .

div.head: Technical development
div.p: The project is based at King's Digital Lab, King's College London.
Arianna Ciula, ORCID (KDL), Deputy Director and Senior Research Software Analyst, supported requirements elicitation as part of KDL effort on archiving and sustainability of legacy projects.
Ginestra Ferraro ORCID (KDL), Senior Research Software UI/UX Designer, contributed to the design of IRT, IRCyr and HGL.
Neil Jakeman, ORCID (KDL), Senior Research Software Analyst, refined the development and front-end of HGL, still hosted at KDL.
Brian Maher, ORCID (KDL), Senior Research Software Engineer and Systems Administrator, responsible for the physical infrastructure on which IRT is currently hosted.
Pam Mellen (KDL), Research Software Project Manager responsible for managing KDL archiving and sustainability effort.
Jamie Norrish (CCH/DDH), independent Developer, worked on EFES.
Miguel Vieira (KDL), Principal Research Software Engineer, worked on the architecture and development of Kiln on which EFES is based.
Tim Watts (KDL), Senior Research Software Systems Manager, is responsible for the physical infrastructure on which IRT is currently hosted.
